Data.event_text: 1 January  Regulator Ofgem introduces a new energy price cap for households in England, Scotland and Wales.

links.text: -"Energy price cap comes into force". BBC News. 1 January 2019. Retrieved 1 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: 2 January  Rail fares in England and Wales rise by an average of 3.1%. Meanwhile, ScotRail announces average rail fare increases of 2.8%.

links.text: -"Rail fares rise by 3.1% in England and Wales". BBC News. 2 January 2019. Retrieved 2 January 2019.-
-"ScotRail 'rip-off' rail fares condemned as tickets increase by 2.8%". BBC News. 2 January 2019. Retrieved 2 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: 3 January  The bakery chain Greggs launches a meat free version of its sausage rolls.

links.text: -"Greggs vegan sausage rolls: Londoners split on 'insanely popular' pastry as some stores in capital sell out". London Evening Standard. 3 January 2019. Retrieved 8 January 2019.-
-Williams, Zoe (7 January 2019). "Half-baked: what Greggs' vegan sausage roll says about Brexit Britain". The Guardian. Retrieved 8 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: 4 January  The engineering arm of collapsed Monarch Airlines falls into administration, with the loss of 450 jobs.

links.text: -"Hundreds of jobs lost as Monarch airline's engineering arm goes into administration". MSN.-

Data.event_text: 7 January  A 10-year plan for NHS England is unveiled. As a result of Barnett consequentials, a proportionate share of extra funding will be transferred to the Scottish Parliament, Welsh Assembly and Northern Ireland Executive.

links.text: -"NHS long-term plan: Focus on prevention 'could save 500,000 lives'". BBC. 7 January 2019. Retrieved 7 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: 8 January  MPs back an amendment to the Finance Bill, by 303 to 296 votes, to limit the Treasury's powers in a no-deal Brexit scenario.

links.text: -"Brexit: MPs defeat government over no-deal preparations". BBC. 8 January 2019. Retrieved 8 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: 9 January  MPs back Dominic Grieve's amendment to the EU withdrawal agreement, by 308 to 297 votes, compelling the government to return to Parliament within three days if the deal is voted down the following week.

links.text: -"Brexit: MPs' vote piles fresh pressure on Theresa May". BBC. 9 January 2019. Retrieved 9 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: 14 January  Conservative Party whip Gareth Johnson resigns, saying he cannot support the government in the forthcoming vote on Theresa May's Brexit withdrawal agreement.

links.text: -"Brexit: Theresa May urges MPs to 'take a second look' at her deal â€“ Politics live". The Guardian. 14 January 2019. Retrieved 14 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: 15 January  The House of Commons rejects Theresa May's deal on the UK's withdrawal from the European Union by 432 votes to 202. The 230 vote margin is the largest defeat for a government motion in 100 years.

links.text: -"PM's Brexit deal rejected by 230 votes". 15 January 2019. Retrieved 15 January 2019.-
-"Brexit deal: How did your MP vote?". 15 January 2019. Retrieved 15 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: 16 January  Theresa May's government survives a no confidence vote by 325 to 306.

links.text: -"May's government survives no confidence vote". BBC. 16 January 2019. Retrieved 16 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: The 97-year-old Duke of Edinburgh, Prince Philip is involved in a car crash while driving near the Queen's Sandringham estate. He is unhurt, "but very, very shocked and shaken."

links.text: -"Prince Philip unhurt in crash while driving". BBC. 17 January 2019. Retrieved 17 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: Japan's Hitachi announces the suspension of work on the Â£20bn Wylfa Newydd nuclear plant in Wales amid concerns over rising costs, putting thousands of jobs at risk.

links.text: -"Wylfa Newydd: Hitachi to halt work on UK nuclear plant". BBC. 17 January 2019. Retrieved 17 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: Theresa May outlines her Brexit "plan B" to the House of Commons, scrapping the Â£65 fee EU citizens were going to have to pay to secure a right to live in the UK after Brexit.

links.text: -"Brexit: Theresa May scraps Â£65 fee for EU citizens to stay in UK". BBC. 21 January 2019. Retrieved 21 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: Three separate security alerts are raised after reports of car hijackings in Derry, two days after a bomb exploded in a car outside its courthouse.

links.text: -"Londonderry bombing: Third alert follows weekend attack". BBC. 21 January 2019. Retrieved 21 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: 2019 Piper PA-46 Malibu crash An aircraft carrying newly-signed Cardiff City F.C. footballer Emiliano Sala and pilot David Ibbotson en route from Nantes, France, to Cardiff, Wales, goes missing over the English Channel. Sala's body is recovered on 7 February.

links.text: -"Emiliano Sala: Missing Cardiff City footballer search continues". BBC News. 24 January 2019. Retrieved 11 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: The EU confirms it will enforce a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic in the event of a no-deal Brexit, despite the risk it would pose to peace.

links.text: -"No-deal Brexit would mean hard Irish border, EU confirms". The Guardian. 22 January 2019. Retrieved 22 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: The UK cafÃ© chain Patisserie Valerie collapses into administration after rescue talks with banks fail.

links.text: -"Patisserie Valerie collapses into administration as rescue talks fail". BBC. 22 January 2019. Retrieved 23 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: 24 January  Former Scottish First Minister Alex Salmond is arrested by police and charged with multiple counts of sexual assault and two of attempted rape.

links.text: -"Former Scottish First Minister Alex Salmond arrested". BBC. 24 January 2019. Retrieved 24 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: 25 January  The European Medicines Agency (EMA) closes its office at Canary Wharf, London, in preparation for its move to Amsterdam.

links.text: -"Key EU medicines regulator closes London office with loss of 900 jobs". The Guardian. 26 January 2019. Retrieved 26 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: 28 January  A letter from the British Retail Consortium, signed by major food retailers including Asda, McDonald's and Sainsbury's, warns of empty shelves and higher prices in the event of a no-deal Brexit.

links.text: -"No-deal Brexit 'to leave shelves empty' warn retailers". BBC. 28 January 2019. Retrieved 28 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: MPs vote on a series of seven Brexit amendments. This includes a proposal to renegotiate the Irish backstop, which is passed with a majority of 16.

links.text: -"Brexit amendments: What did MPs vote on and what were the results?". BBC. 29 January 2019. Retrieved 29 January 2019.-
-"Full list: amendments to May's statement on defeat of her Brexit bill". The Guardian. 29 January 2019. Retrieved 29 January 2019.-
-"Brexit: MPs back May's bid to change deal". BBC News. BBC. 29 January 2019. Retrieved 30 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: Labour MP for Peterborough Fiona Onasanya is sentenced to three months imprisonment having earlier been found guilty of perverting the course of justice for lying about who was driving her car when caught speeding. Her imprisonment makes her the first sitting MP to be jailed in 28 years.

links.text: -Yorke, Harry; Hardy, Jack (29 January 2019). "Fiona Onasanya will continue to receive taxpayer-funded salary in prison after becoming first sitting MP to be jailed in three decadesÃ‚". The Daily Telegraph.-

Data.event_text: The EU's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, rejects calls to reopen the Brexit deal and says the Irish backstop will not be renegotiated, despite the UK's request.

links.text: -"Brexit: Backstop is 'part and parcel' of the deal, says Michel Barnier". BBC News. BBC. 30 January 2019. Retrieved 30 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: A High Court judge approves a Â£166bn (â‚¬190bn) transfer of assets by Barclays bank to its Irish division as a result of Brexit disruption.

links.text: -"Barclays prepares to trigger Â£166bn no-deal Brexit plan". Sky News. 30 January 2019. Retrieved 30 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: 31 January  A report by the Society of Motor Manufacturers (SMMT) states that investment in the British car industry fell by 46.5% in 2018 as a result of Brexit uncertainty.

links.text: -"Brexit: Car investment halves as industry hits 'red alert'". BBC News. BBC. 31 January 2019. Retrieved 31 January 2019.-
-"Brexit slashes car industry investment by nearly 50 percent". DW. 31 January 2019. Retrieved 31 January 2019.-

Data.event_text: Hundreds of schools across Wales and southern parts of England are closed due to snow and icy conditions.

links.text: -"Hundreds of schools shut after snow". BBC Newa. 1 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: Leave.EU and Eldon Insurance owned by its founder Arron Banks are fined Â£120,000 over data law breaches.

links.text: -"Brexit: Leave.EU and Arron Banks' firm fined Â£120,000 over data breaches". BBC News. BBC. 1 February 2019. Retrieved 1 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: A 37-year-old mother who mutilated her three-year-old daughter becomes the first person in the UK to be found guilty of female genital mutilation (FGM).

links.text: -"FGM: Mother guilty of genital mutilation of daughter". BBC News. BBC. 1 February 2019. Retrieved 1 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: Apetito and Bidfood, two major suppliers to care homes and hospitals, report that they are stockpiling food in case of disruption caused by Brexit.

links.text: -"Brexit: Care home and hospital caterers stockpiling food". BBC News. BBC. 3 February 2019. Retrieved 3 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: Car manufacturer Nissan confirms that it will not be moving production of its X-Trail SUV from Japan to Sunderland, citing the falling sales of diesel cars in Europe as the reason, adding that "While we have taken this decision for business reasons, the continued uncertainty around the UK's future relationship with the EU is not helping companies like ours to plan for the future".

links.text: -"Nissan faces losing Theresa May's Â£60m Brexit sweetener". The Times. 4 February 2019. Retrieved 4 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: 4 February  The wreckage of the PA-46 Malibu that was carrying footballer Emiliano Sala and pilot David Ibbotson is found underwater and a body is seen within it.

links.text: -"Body seen in Emiliano Sala plane wreckage". BBC News. 4 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: 5 February  HMV is acquired out of administration by Canadian retailer Sunrise Records, safeguarding the future of nearly 1,500 staff.

links.text: -Angela Monaghan and Sarah Butler (5 February 2019). "HMV reveals which 27 stores have closed after sale to Canadian music boss". The Guardian. Retrieved 6 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: The Office for National Statistics reports that knife crime in England and Wales is at its highest level since records began in 1946, with the number of fatal stabbings the previous year being the most ever reported.

links.text: -"Knife crime: Fatal stabbings at highest level since records began in 1946". BBC News. 7 February 2019. Retrieved 7 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: The Bank of England keeps interest rates on hold at 0.75%, but warns of a slowdown in economic growth during 2019, which it says could be the worst year since 2009.

links.text: -"Bank forecasts worst year for UK since 2009". BBC News. 7 February 2019. Retrieved 7 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) cancels all horse racing in Great Britain until at least 13 February after an outbreak of equine influenza.

links.text: -"Equine Flu: British horse racing cancelled until at least 13 February". BBC News. 7 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: A body is recovered from the wreckage of the PA-46 Malibu which vanished over the English Channel on 21 January. Dorset Police later identify it as that of Emiliano Sala.

links.text: -"Emiliano Sala: Body identified as Cardiff City footballer". BBC News. 8 February 2019. Retrieved 11 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: 14 February  Theresa May suffers a fresh defeat in the Commons on her Brexit strategy, losing the vote by 303 to 258.

links.text: -"Brexit: Theresa May suffers fresh Commons defeat". BBC News. 14 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: 15 February  Thousands of school pupils around the UK go on strike as part of a global campaign for action on climate change.

links.text: -"Climate strike: Schoolchildren protest over climate change". BBC News. 15 February 2019. Retrieved 15 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: 16 February  Regional airline Flybmi ceases operations and files for administration, blaming Brexit as the main cause of its collapse.

links.text: -"Flybmi collapses, blaming Brexit uncertainty". The Guardian. 16 February 2019. Retrieved 16 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: Seven MPs  Chuka Umunna, Luciana Berger, Chris Leslie, Angela Smith, Mike Gapes, Gavin Shuker and Ann Coffey  announce that they have resigned from the Labour Party to form The Independent Group.

links.text: -"Seven MPs leave Labour Party". BBC News. 18 February 2019. Retrieved 18 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: Plans by Japanese carmaker Honda to close its Swindon factory by 2022 are leaked to the press, a day before the official announcement.

links.text: -"Honda to stun ministers with closure of Swindon factory". Sky News. 18 February 2019. Retrieved 18 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: 19 February  MP Joan Ryan resigns from the Labour Party to join The Independent Group.

links.text: -Zeffman, Henry; Devlin, Kate (19 February 2019). "Joan Ryan is eighth Labour MP to quit, blaming 'Corbyn culture of antisemitism'". The Times. Retrieved 19 February 2019.-

-Kirby, Will (19 February 2019). "Joan Ryan: Labour MP resigns from party to join Independent Group, accusing Jeremy Corbyn of 'playing games with Brexit'". The Independent. Archived from the original on 20 February 2019. Retrieved 19 February 2019.-

-Kirby, Will (19 February 2019). "Joan Ryan: Labour MP resigns from party to join Independent Group, accusing Jeremy Corbyn of 'playing games with Brexit'". The Independent. Archived from the original on 20 February 2019. Retrieved 19 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: Three Conservative Party MPs  Heidi Allen, Sarah Wollaston and Anna Soubry  resign from their party to join The Independent Group.

links.text: -"Three MPs quit Tory party to join breakaway group". BBC News. 20 February 2019. Retrieved 20 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: Home Secretary Sajid Javid confirms the intention to strip Shamima Begum, who left the UK as a teenager to join Islamic State in Syria in 2015, of her UK citizenship.

links.text: -"Shamima Begum: IS teenager to lose UK citizenship". BBC News. 20 February 2019. Retrieved 20 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: 21 February  The youth was found guilty through a unanimous verdict for the abduction, rape and murder of six-year-old Alesha MacPhail on the 2 July 2018. Lord Matthews described the events as "committing some of the most wicked and evil crimes this court has ever heard of in decades of dealing with depravity." The judge also agreed to reverse the naming restriction due to the â€˜uniqueâ€™ nature of the case - the first in Scottish history - and the defendant is named as 16-year-old Aaron Campbell.

links.text: -"Alesha MacPhail murder: Boy, 16, found guilty". 21 February 2019. Retrieved 23 March 2025.-
-Brooks, Libby (22 February 2019). "Teenage murderer of Alesha MacPhail named as Aaron Campbell". The Guardian. ISSNÂ 0261-3077. Retrieved 23 March 2025.-
-Brooks, Libby (22 February 2019). "Teenage murderer of Alesha MacPhail named as Aaron Campbell". The Guardian. ISSNÂ 0261-3077. Retrieved 23 March 2025.-

Data.event_text: 22 February  Dudley North MP Ian Austin resigns from the Labour Party saying the party has failed to tackle antisemitism, but says he has no plans to join the Independent Group.

links.text: -"Ian Austin quits Labour blaming Jeremy Corbyn's leadership". BBC News. 22 February 2019. Retrieved 22 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: 23 February  Roy Hodgson becomes the oldest man to manage in the Premier League (with Crystal Palace F.C.), at the age of 71 years and 198 days.

links.text: -Simon Stone (23 February 2019). "Roy Hodgson: The Premier League's oldest manager â€“ by those who know him best". BBC Sport. Retrieved 23 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: 25 February  A temperature of 20.3Â Â°C (68.5Â Â°F) is reported in Trawsgoed, Ceredigion, the UK's highest on record for the month of February.

links.text: -Simon Stone (25 February 2019). "UK basks in warmest February day on record". BBC News. Retrieved 25 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: The Shadow Brexit Secretary, Keir Starmer states that Labour will back a second EU referendum with remain on the ballot if Theresa May's deal gets through parliament.

links.text: -"Keir Starmer: Labour's Brexit stance is either credible deal or remain". The Guardian. 26 February 2019. Retrieved 26 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: Theresa May states that MPs will be given the choice between no-deal Brexit or a Brexit delay, if they reject her plan the following month.

links.text: -"Theresa May to offer MPs no-deal Brexit vote". BBC News. 26 February 2019. Retrieved 26 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: The government publishes its assessment of the impact of a no-deal Brexit.

links.text: -"Implications for Business and Trade of a No Deal Exit on 29 March 2019" (PDF). HM government. Retrieved 26 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: The UK winter temperature record is broken for a second consecutive day, as the Met Office records 21.2Â Â°C (70.2Â Â°F) in Kew Gardens, London. Various huge wildfires are reported, the largest being at Saddleworth Moor in West Yorkshire.

links.text: -"UK breaks winter temperature record again". BBC News. 26 February 2019. Retrieved 26 February 2019.-
-"Wildfires burn across UK amid highest winter temperatures ever recorded". The Independent. 27 February 2019. Archived from the original on 28 February 2019. Retrieved 27 February 2019.-
-"Wildfires burn across UK amid highest winter temperatures ever recorded". The Independent. 27 February 2019. Archived from the original on 28 February 2019. Retrieved 27 February 2019.-

Data.event_text: 1 March  The UK Government announces it has paid out Â£33,000,000 to settle a dispute with Eurotunnel over the awarding of ferry contracts, which was led by Transport Secretary Chris Grayling, to cope with a no-deal Brexit.

links.text: -"Government pays Eurotunnel Â£33m over Brexit ferry case". BBC News. 1 March 2019. Retrieved 1 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: Luxury fashion retailer LK Bennett goes into administration.

links.text: -"Retailer LK Bennett goes into administration". BBC News. 7 March 2019. Retrieved 7 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: The Institute and Faculty of Actuaries reports evidence of slowing life expectancy in the UK, which first emerged in 20102011 and is now "a trend as opposed to a blip".

links.text: -"Life expectancy falls by six months in biggest drop in UK forecasts". The Guardian. 7 March 2019. Retrieved 7 March 2019.-
-"Longer term influences driving lower life expectancy projections". Institute and Faculty of Actuaries. 7 March 2019. Retrieved 7 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: The House of Commons rejects Theresa May's deal on the UK's withdrawal from the European Union for a second time, by 391 votes to 242.

links.text: -"Brexit: MPs reject Theresa May's deal by 149 votes". BBC News. 12 March 2019. Retrieved 12 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: Three climbers are killed and another injured in an avalanche on Ben Nevis.

links.text: -"Third person dead after Ben Nevis avalanche". BBC News. 12 March 2019. Retrieved 12 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: MPs vote by 321 votes to 278 to accept an amended government motion to reject the UK leaving the European Union without a deal.

links.text: -"MPs vote to reject no-deal Brexit". BBC News. 13 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: Chancellor Philip Hammond says that gas heating for new houses will be prohibited by a date which he gives as 2025, although gas hobs will still be allowed.

links.text: -"Gas heating ban for new homes from 2025". BBC News. 13 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: 14 March  MPs vote by 412 to 202 in favour of requesting that the UK's withdrawal from the European Union be delayed beyond 29 March.

links.text: -"Brexit: MPS vote by 412 to 202 to seek delay to EU departure". BBC News. 14 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: 15 March  Thousands of school pupils around the UK go on strike as part of a global campaign for action on climate change.

links.text: -"Climate strike: Schoolchildren protest over climate change". BBC News. 15 March 2019. Retrieved 30 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: 18 March  The Speaker of the House of Commons, John Bercow, quoting a parliamentary rule dating back to 1604, declares that a third "meaningful vote" on the Brexit deal cannot proceed unless it contains substantial changes. Ministers warn of a "constitutional crisis", with just eleven days until the UK is due to leave the EU.

links.text: -"Third Brexit vote must be different â€“ Speaker". BBC News. 18 March 2019. Retrieved 18 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: 20 March  Prime Minister Theresa May writes a letter to EU Council President Donald Tusk, requesting a three-month extension to Article 50.

links.text: -"Theresa May asks EU for Brexit delay until 30 June". The Guardian. 20 March 2019. Retrieved 20 March 2019.-
-"Brexit: Theresa May vows not to delay departure beyond June". BBC News. 20 March 2019. Retrieved 20 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: The TUC and CBI write a letter to the Prime Minister saying the UK faces a "national emergency" due to Brexit and urging May to embrace an alternative plan.

links.text: -"Theresa May told to change path on Brexit by industry and union leaders". City AM. 21 March 2019. Retrieved 21 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: The EU agrees to delay Brexit until 22 May 2019, if MPs approve a withdrawal deal; or to 12 April if they do not.

links.text: -"EU leaders decide Brexit fate behind closed doors as May secures Article 50 extension". The Independent. 21 March 2019. Archived from the original on 22 March 2019. Retrieved 22 March 2019.-
-"EU leaders decide Brexit fate behind closed doors as May secures Article 50 extension". The Independent. 21 March 2019. Archived from the original on 22 March 2019. Retrieved 22 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: Aaron Campbell was sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 27 years for the murder of six-year-old Alesha MacPhail. Lord Matthews said Campbell's crime had caused "revulsion and disbelief" and described Campbell as a "cold, callous, calculating, remorseless and dangerous individual".

links.text: -"Alesha MacPhail murder: Life sentence for Aaron Campbell after he admits guilt". 21 March 2019. Retrieved 23 March 2025.-

Data.event_text: 23 March  Hundreds of thousands of protesters flock to London for the second People's Vote march, asking the UK Government for a second referendum on leaving the EU and to permanently revoke Article 50.

links.text: -"Brexit march: Hundreds of thousands join referendum protest". BBC News. 23 March 2019. Retrieved 23 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: 24 March  An online e-petition calling on the government to revoke Article 50 reaches 5,000,000 signatures.

links.text: -"Petition to revoke Article 50 and remain in EU reaches 5 million signatures". The National. 24 March 2019. Retrieved 24 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: 25 March  MPs defeat the government by 329 to 302 as they vote in favour of an amendment by Oliver Letwin, giving Parliament the option to hold a series of "indicative votes" on Brexit.[clarification needed]

links.text: -"MPs seize control of Brexit process by backing indicative votes amendment". The Guardian. 25 March 2019. Retrieved 26 March 2019.-
-"British MPs vote to seize control of Brexit". Financial Times. 25 March 2019. Archived from the original on 26 March 2019. Retrieved 29 March 2019.-
-"British MPs vote to seize control of Brexit". Financial Times. 25 March 2019. Archived from the original on 26 March 2019. Retrieved 29 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: 26 March  The European Parliament votes by 348 to 278 in favour of the controversial Article 13 of the European Union Directive on Copyright in the Digital Single Market, which expands legal liability for websites.

links.text: -"Article 13: Memes exempt as EU backs controversial copyright law". BBC News. 26 March 2019. Retrieved 26 March 2019.-
-"European Parliament approves new copyright rules for the internet". European Parliament. 26 March 2019. Retrieved 26 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: The Department for Transport says that the United Kingdom will adopt speed limiting technology that will become mandatory for all new vehicles sold in Europe from 2022, after new rules were provisionally agreed by the European Union.

links.text: -"Road safety: UK set to adopt vehicle speed limiters". BBC News. 27 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: MPs back the statutory instrument changing the Brexit date in the EU Withdrawal Act by 441 votes to 105, a majority of 336.

links.text: -Cooper, Charlie (27 March 2019). "MPs enshrine Brexit delay in UK law". POLITICO. Retrieved 29 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: None of MPs' eight proposed options (indicative votes) for Brexit gains a majority following a House of Commons vote.

links.text: -"Brexit: No majority for any options after MPs' votes". BBC News. 27 March 2019. Retrieved 28 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: The recently formed Independent Group applies to become a political party with the name "Change UK  The Independent Group" and names Heidi Allen as interim leader.

links.text: -"Independent Group of MPs to become political party". BBC News. 29 March 2019. Retrieved 29 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: MPs reject Theresa May's EU withdrawal agreement for a third time, by 344 votes to 286.

links.text: -"MPs reject May's EU withdrawal agreement". BBC News. 29 March 2019. Retrieved 29 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: A motion of no confidence against pro-EU Conservative MP Dominic Grieve is carried by his local party, 182 votes to 131.

links.text: -"Dominic Grieve loses confidence vote held by Beaconsfield Tories". The Guardian. 30 March 2019. Retrieved 1 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: 31 March  The e-petition calling on the UK Government to revoke Article 50 reaches 6,000,000 signatures, doing so a day before it is due to be debated by parliament.

links.text: -Forrest, Adam (31 March 2019). "Revoke Article 50 petition calling for Brexit to be cancelled hits 6 million signatures". The Independent. Archived from the original on 31 March 2019. Retrieved 31 March 2019.-

-Forrest, Adam (31 March 2019). "Revoke Article 50 petition calling for Brexit to be cancelled hits 6 million signatures". The Independent. Archived from the original on 31 March 2019. Retrieved 31 March 2019.-

Data.event_text: For the second time, none of four proposed options (indicative votes) for Brexit gain a majority following a House of Commons vote. A customs union with the EU, a "Common Market 2.0", a second referendum and a vote on whether to revoke Article 50 all fail to win clear backing from MPs.
Immediately following the indicative votes on Brexit, MP Nick Boles quits the Conservative party, with a speech criticising his former colleagues for refusing to compromise on the options.
The UK's National Living Wage rises from Â£7.83 to Â£8.21, an increase of 4.9%.

links.text: -"Minimum wage rates rise, but bills go up too". BBC News. 1 April 2019. Retrieved 1 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: London Liverpool Street, London King's Cross and Edinburgh Waverley become the last of Network Rail's stations to abolish charges to their public toilets.

links.text: -"Toilet charges scrapped at busiest railway stations". BBC News. 1 April 2019. Retrieved 1 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: 2 April  In a statement following a Cabinet meeting, Prime Minister Theresa May announces her intention to extend Article 50 again and work with Opposition Leader Jeremy Corbyn on a plan, but keep the withdrawal agreement as part of her deal.

links.text: -"Brexit: Theresa May to ask EU for further extension". BBC News. 2 April 2019. Retrieved 2 April 2019.-
-"Brexit: May to ask for short article 50 extension and offers to meet Labour leader â€“ live news". The Guardian. 2 April 2019. Retrieved 2 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: Prosecutors seek a retrial in the case of the police match commander at the Hillsborough disaster David Duckenfield, after a jury fails to reach a verdict.

links.text: -"Hillsborough trial: No verdict over David Duckenfield". BBC News. 3 April 2019. Retrieved 3 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: A bill by Labour MP Yvette Cooper to force the Prime Minister to ask the EU for an extension to Article 50, in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit, passes the House of Commons by 313 votes to 312.

links.text: -"Brexit: MPs back delay bill by one vote". BBC News. 4 April 2019. Retrieved 4 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: 5 April  Theresa May writes to the EU requesting a Brexit extension until 30 June 2019. EU ministers respond by saying the letter is too vague to justify an extension being offered.

links.text: -"Brexit: UK asks EU for further extension until 30 June". BBC News. 5 April 2019. Retrieved 5 April 2019.-
-"France maintains hardline stance on no-deal Brexit". The Guardian. 5 April 2019. Retrieved 5 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: 6 April  Tiger Roll wins the 2019 Grand National, the second consecutive year it has won the race.

links.text: -"Tiger Roll makes history and wins Grand National 2019 as punters bet Â£150m". ITV News. 6 April 2019. Retrieved 6 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: Jaguar Land Rover shuts down production for a week because of uncertainties around Brexit.

links.text: -"Jaguar Land Rover starts Brexit shutdown". BBC News. 8 April 2019. Retrieved 8 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: London's Ultra Low Emission Zone comes into effect.

links.text: -"ULEZ: New pollution charge begins in London". BBC News. 8 April 2019. Retrieved 8 April 2019.-
-"Heart charity urges other cities to follow London's ultra-low emission zone". The Guardian. 7 April 2019. Retrieved 8 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: 9 April  Department store Debenhams goes into administration, after a last-ditch rescue offer from Mike Ashley's Sports Direct was rejected.

links.text: -"Debenhams falls into hands of lenders". BBC News. 9 April 2019. Retrieved 9 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: 10 April  The UK and the EU agree an Article 50 extension to 31 October 2019. No reopening of the withdrawal agreement negotiations is allowed and the UK "must hold the elections to the European Parliament" on 23 May, or it will be forced to leave on 1 June 2019.

links.text: -"Brexit: UK and EU agree delay to 31 October". BBC News. 11 April 2019. Retrieved 11 April 2019.-
-"Theresa May agrees to October Brexit as Donald Tusk warns UK 'don't waste this time'". The Guardian. 11 April 2019. Retrieved 11 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: 11 April  WikiLeaks co-founder Julian Assange is arrested after seven years of living in the Ecuadorian embassy in London.

links.text: -"Julian Assange: Wikileaks co-founder arrested in London". BBC News. 11 April 2019. Retrieved 11 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: 12 April  Former UKIP leader Nigel Farage launches the Brexit Party.

links.text: -"Nigel Farage launches Brexit Party ahead of European elections". BBC News. 12 April 2019. Retrieved 12 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: 1522 April  Demonstrations by the climate change activist group Extinction Rebellion cause disruption in central London, blocking roads and resulting in over 1,000 arrests, with 53 people charged for various offences. A "pause" in the protest is announced on 21 April, although the group continues to base itself in Marble Arch.

links.text: -"Extinction Rebellion London protest: 290 arrested". BBC News. 16 April 2019. Retrieved 17 April 2019.-
-"Extinction Rebellion London protests enter third day". BBC News. 17 April 2019. Retrieved 17 April 2019.-
-"Extinction Rebellion: Climate protests 'diverting' London police". BBC News. 18 April 2019.-
-"Extinction Rebellion to 'pause' London protests". BBC News. 21 April 2019. Retrieved 21 April 2019.-
-"Extinction Rebellion: Climate change protest arrest reach 1,000". BBC News. 22 April 2019. Retrieved 22 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: 17 April  The UK Government announces it will introduce an age verification system designed to stop internet users under the age of eighteen from viewing pornographic websites, which will come into force on 15 July but in practice is never brought into effect.
18 April  29-year-old journalist and author Lyra McKee is shot dead amid rioting in Derry, Northern Ireland, with police treating it as a "terrorist incident" and suspecting the New IRA.

links.text: -"Journalist shot dead in Derry during rioting in the city". BBC News. 19 April 2019. Retrieved 19 April 2019.-
-"Journalist killed in Derry 'terrorist incident', say Northern Ireland police". The Guardian. 19 April 2019. Retrieved 19 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: Leaders from 70 local Conservative Associations sign a petition calling for a vote of no confidence in Theresa May. The non-binding vote, to be determined by 800 of the party's senior officials, would be the first time such an instance has occurred.

links.text: -"PM to face grassroots no-confidence vote". BBC News. 22 April 2019. Retrieved 22 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: The hottest Easter Monday on record in all four nations of the UK is confirmed by the Met Office, with 25Â Â°C (77Â Â°F) reported at Heathrow, Northolt and Wisley.

links.text: -"UK weather: Hottest Easter Monday on record". BBC News. 22 April 2019. Retrieved 22 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: 24 April  The Conservative Party's 1922 Committee votes against changing the party's rules regarding leadership challenges, but asks for clarity on when Prime Minister Theresa May will step down from office.

links.text: -"Theresa May: Senior Tories rule out early challenge to PM". BBC News. BBC. 24 April 2019. Retrieved 24 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: The government announces it will launch a formal inquiry into the leaking of discussions about Chinese telecommunications firm Huawei at the National Security Council after  The Daily Telegraph published details of a meeting concerning plans to use the firm to help build the 5G network.

links.text: -"Huawei row: Inquiry 'being held' into National Security Council leak". BBC News. BBC. 25 April 2019. Retrieved 25 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: The Foreign Office warns against all but essential travel to Sri Lanka following the Easter Sunday bombings in which eight Britons were among the dead.

links.text: -"UK warns against all but essential Sri Lanka travel". BBC News. BBC. 25 April 2019. Retrieved 25 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: Prime Minister Theresa May and Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar issue a joint statement setting out a new process of talks designed to restore devolution to Northern Ireland, to begin on 7 May.

links.text: -"New Northern Ireland talks process to begin on May 7". BBC News. BBC. 26 April 2019. Retrieved 26 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: Department store Debenhams announces plans to close 22 branches in 2019.

links.text: -"Debenhams names 22 stores to close". BBC News. BBC. 26 April 2019. Retrieved 26 April 2019.-

Data.event_text: Peterborough Member of Parliament Fiona Onasanya becomes the first MP to be removed by a recall petition after 19,261 of her constituents voted for her to be removed from office. Onasanya's recall petition had been automatically triggered as a result of her conviction for perverting the course of justice, an offence for which she was imprisoned in January.

links.text: -"MP first to be ousted under recall rules". BBC News. 1 May 2019.-
-Will Humphries, Kate Devlin (2 May 2019). "Fiona Onasanya becomes first MP to be ousted by recall petition". The Times.-

Data.event_text: WikiLeaks co-founder Julian Assange is sentenced to 50 weeks in jail for breaching bail conditions.

links.text: -"Julian Assange: WikiLeaks co-founder jailed over bail breach". BBC News. BBC. 1 May 2019. Retrieved 1 May 2019.-

Data.event_text: Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson is dismissed after a leak from a National Security Council meeting in which plans by Chinese firm Huawei to contribute to the UK's 5G network were discussed. He is replaced by Penny Mordaunt.

links.text: -"Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson sacked over Huawei leak". BBC News. 1 May 2019. Retrieved 1 May 2019.-

Data.event_text: 2 May  2019 United Kingdom local elections The Lib Dems, Greens and independents make gains in the local elections at the expense of the Conservatives, while Labour and UKIP also suffer losses.

links.text: -"Local elections: Conservatives lose more than 1,300 councillors". BBC News. BBC. 3 May 2019. Retrieved 4 May 2019.-

Data.event_text: 4 May  The Metropolitan Police says that the National Security Council leak about Huawei "did not amount to a criminal offence".

links.text: -"Huawei leak did not amount to criminal offence, police say". BBC News. BBC. 4 May 2019. Retrieved 4 May 2019.-

Data.event_text: The Duchess of Sussex gives birth to a son, Archie Mountbatten-Windsor.
The World Snooker Championship concludes with Judd Trump defeating John Higgins 189 in the final to win his first world title.

links.text: -"World Championship 2019: Judd Trump beats John Higgins 18â€“9 in Crucible final". 6 May 2019. Retrieved 7 May 2019.-

Data.event_text: 8 May  A British teenager, Isabelle Holdaway, 17, is reported to be the first patient to receive a genetically modified phage therapy to treat a drug-resistant infection.

links.text: -"Teenager recovers from near death in world-first GM virus treatment". The Guardian. 8 May 2019. Retrieved 9 May 2019.-
-"Phage therapy: 'Viral cocktail saved my daughter's life'". BBC News. 8 May 2019. Retrieved 9 May 2019.-

Data.event_text: 9 May  Broadcaster Danny Baker is dismissed from BBC Radio 5 Live after tweeting a "royal baby" image of a chimpanzee.

links.text: -"Danny Baker fired by BBC over royal baby chimp tweet". BBC News. 9 May 2019. Retrieved 9 May 2019.-

Data.event_text: 13 May  The Jeremy Kyle Show is suspended indefinitely following the death of a participant shortly after appearing on an unbroadcast programme. The show is axed by ITV two days later.

links.text: -"The Jeremy Kyle Show off air and suspended indefinitely after death of guest". ITV. 13 May 2019. Retrieved 13 May 2019.-
-"The Jeremy Kyle Show axed by ITV after death of guest". BBC News. 15 May 2019. Retrieved 15 May 2019.-

Data.event_text: 16 May  Boris Johnson confirms that he will run for the Conservative Party leadership after Theresa May stands down.

links.text: -"Boris Johnson confirms bid for Tory leadership". BBC News. 16 May 2019. Retrieved 16 May 2019.-

Data.event_text: Brexit talks between Labour and the Conservatives end without agreement, following six weeks of cross-party debate, with Jeremy Corbyn saying negotiations have "gone as far as they can."

links.text: -"Brexit: Jeremy Corbyn says cross-party talks have 'gone as far as they can'". BBC News. 17 May 2019. Retrieved 17 May 2019.-

Data.event_text: The Ministry of Justice announces plans to introduce "Helen's Law", which would require a person convicted of murder without the presence of a body to reveal the location of their victim's remains before being considered for parole.

links.text: -"Marie McCourt: Helen's Law 'will help other families'". BBC News. BBC. 17 May 2019. Retrieved 17 May 2019.-

Data.event_text: 1 June  In the first all-English UEFA Champions League final since 2008, Liverpool defeat Tottenham Hotspur 20 at the Metropolitano Stadium in Madrid, Spain. This is Liverpool's sixth European Cup title.

links.text: -McNulty, Phil (1 June 2019). "Liverpool beat Spurs 2-0 to win Champions League final in Madrid". BBC Sport. Retrieved 19 May 2020.-

Data.event_text: 3 June  U.S. President Donald Trump begins a three-day state visit to the UK.

links.text: -"Donald Trump praises 'eternal friendship' at state banquet". BBC News. BBC. 3 June 2019. Retrieved 5 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: 4 June  Six Change UK MPs  Luciana Berger, Gavin Shuker, Angela Smith, Chuka Umunna, Sarah Wollaston and interim party leader Heidi Allen â€“ announce their resignation from the party. The remaining five MPs, remain in the party, with Brexit and Justice spokeswoman Anna Soubry becoming leader.
American carmaker Ford announces the closure of its Ford Bridgend Engine Plant in September 2020, with the loss of 1,700 jobs.

links.text: -"Ford set to close Bridgend engine plant in 2020". BBC News. 6 June 2019. Retrieved 6 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: Peterborough by election Labour retains the seat, with the Brexit Party finishing in second place and the Conservatives in third. The by-election was held because of the previous Labour MP having been removed as the result of a recall petition.
7 June  Prime Minister Theresa May resigns as Leader of the Conservative Party, paving the way for a leadership contest.

links.text: -"Theresa May resignation: How the UK's next prime minister will be chosen". BBC News. 7 June 2019. Retrieved 7 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: 10 June  The BBC announces that, from , it will stop providing free television licences for over-75s who do not receive pension credit.

links.text: -"TV licences: Up to 3.7 million over-75s to pay licence fee". BBC News. 10 June 2019. Retrieved 10 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: Theresa May announces a new legally binding target to reach net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, making the United Kingdom the first major industrialised nation to propose this goal.

links.text: -"Climate change: UK government to commit to 2050 target". BBC News. 12 June 2019. Retrieved 12 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: In a vote of 309298, MPs reject a plan by Labour to take control of Parliament's timetable, which would have enabled the tabling of legislation to prevent a no-deal Brexit on 31 October.

links.text: -"Brexit: MPs reject Labour plan for no-deal vote". BBC News. 12 June 2019. Retrieved 12 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: 13 June  Former Labour MP, then-Change UK MP, then Independent MP, Chuka Umunna, defects to the Liberal Democrats.

links.text: -"Chuka Umunna joins the Lib Dems after quitting Change UK". BBC News. BBC. 13 June 2019. Retrieved 13 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: 18 June  Heathrow Airport publishes a masterplan for construction of a third runway by 2026 and completion of the airport's expansion by 2050.

links.text: -"Heathrow reveals expansion 'masterplan'". BBC News. 18 June 2019. Retrieved 18 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: Tendai Muswere becomes the first person in the UK to be convicted of illegally manufacturing a firearm using a 3D printer.

links.text: -"Man guilty of making a gun using a 3D printer". BBC News. 19 June 2019. Retrieved 19 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: The Isle of Wight is awarded "Biosphere Reserve" status by UNESCO, becoming the seventh UK location to receive this designation.

links.text: -"Isle of Wight joins Unesco's network of biosphere sites". BBC News. 19 June 2019. Retrieved 19 June 2019.-
-"18 New sites join UNESCO's World Network of Biosphere Reserves". UNESCO. 19 June 2019. Retrieved 19 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: 20 June  In a case brought by Campaign Against Arms Trade, the Court of Appeal rules that UK arms sales to Saudi Arabia are unlawful.

links.text: -"UK arms sales to Saudi Arabia unlawful, court rules". BBC News. 20 June 2019. Retrieved 20 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: Conservative Party MP Chris Davies loses his seat after a recall petition in response to his conviction for submitting false expenses claims. This forces a by-election in Brecon and Radnorshire.

links.text: -"Convicted Tory MP Chris Davies loses seat after recall petition". The Guardian. 21 June 2019. Retrieved 22 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: Conservative Party MP Mark Field is suspended as a Minister, after video footage shows him grabbing and pushing a female activist who interrupted Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond's Mansion House Speech.

links.text: -"Mark Field suspended as minister after grabbing activist". BBC News. 21 June 2019. Retrieved 21 June 2019.-
-"MP Mark Field accused of assaulting Greenpeace activist". BBC News. 21 June 2019. Retrieved 21 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: 29 June  The Met Office records some of the hottest UK temperatures for June in 40 years, with Heathrow and Northolt in west London reaching 34C (93.2F).

links.text: -"UK weather: Hottest day of the year as temperatures soar". BBC News. BBC. 29 June 2019. Retrieved 29 June 2019.-

Data.event_text: 2 July  FIFA Women's World Cup The most-watched British television broadcast of the year, 11.7 million viewers watch the England football team's 12 defeat to USA in the semi-final in Parc Olympique Lyonnais (Stade de Lyon) in Lyon, France.

links.text: -"England's World Cup defeat to USA watched by 11.7m TV viewers". The Guardian. 3 July 2019. Retrieved 3 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: Eight gang members who ran the biggest modern-day slavery network ever exposed in the UK, involving more than 400 victims in the West Midlands, are jailed with sentences ranging from three to 11 years.

links.text: -"UK slavery network 'had 400 victims'". BBC News. 5 July 2019. Retrieved 5 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: Ex-English Defence League leader Tommy Robinson is found guilty of contempt of court over a Facebook broadcast.

links.text: -"Tommy Robinson guilty over Facebook broadcast". BBC News. 5 July 2019. Retrieved 5 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: Secretary of State for Justice David Gauke confirms that "Helen's Law" will be adopted in England and Wales. This will provide that convicted murderers who have hidden their victims' bodies cannot be considered for parole until they reveal the locations.

links.text: -"Helen's Law: Killers who conceal victims' remains face parole refusal". BBC News. BBC. 5 July 2019. Retrieved 6 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: 7 July  The Trump administration is labelled "inept", "insecure" and "incompetent" in leaked emails from the British Ambassador to the United States, Sir Kim Darroch.

links.text: -"Trump administration is 'inept and insecure', says UK ambassador". BBC News. BBC. 7 July 2019. Retrieved 10 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: 9 July  MPs vote by 294 to 293 in favour of a bid to require ministers to give fortnightly updates on the situation in Northern Ireland. The plan, drawn up by Dominic Grieve, is designed to make it harder for the next prime minister to suspend Parliament and cause a no-deal Brexit.

links.text: -"UK lawmakers back plan to hinder a no-deal Brexit push". Reuters. 9 July 2019. Archived from the original on 10 July 2019. Retrieved 10 July 2019.-
-"UK lawmakers back plan to hinder a no-deal Brexit push". Reuters. 9 July 2019. Archived from the original on 10 July 2019. Retrieved 10 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: Sir Kim Darroch resigns as UK ambassador to the US, amid the ongoing row over leaked emails critical of the Trump administration.

links.text: -"Sir Kim Darroch resigns as UK ambassador to US". BBC News. BBC. 10 July 2019. Retrieved 10 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: Formula One and Silverstone agree a new five-year deal to keep the British Grand Prix on the calendar following two years of renegotiations between Liberty Media and the BRDC.

links.text: -"British Grand Prix: New Silverstone deal announced until 2024". BBC News. BBC. 10 July 2019. Retrieved 10 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: 11 July  Tommy Robinson, having been found guilty of contempt of court on 5 July, is sentenced at the Old Bailey to nine months in prison.

links.text: -"Tommy Robinson jailed over contempt of court". BBC News. BBC. 11 July 2019. Retrieved 11 July 2019.-
-"Tommy Robinson given nine-month jail sentence for contempt of court". The Guardian. 11 July 2019. Retrieved 11 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: The first fatal collision involving an e-scooter in Britain occurs, killing TV presenter and YouTube star Emily Hartridge in Battersea, London.

links.text: -"Television presenter Emily Hartridge dies in e-scooter crash". The Guardian. 13 July 2019. Retrieved 14 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: Former Blue Peter presenter John Leslie is charged with sexually assaulting a 30-year-old woman in Westminster in December 2008.

links.text: -"John Leslie charged with sexual offence". BBC News. 12 July 2019. Retrieved 12 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: 14 July  "Super Sunday" in sport England win the Cricket World Cup final (played at Lord's) for the first time, beating New Zealand on boundary count after a tied match; British driver Lewis Hamilton wins a record sixth Formula 1 British Grand Prix at Silverstone; and in the 2019 Wimbledon Championships  Men's Singles tennis, Novak Djokovic (Serbia) beats Roger Federer (Switzerland) in the longest ever final at four hours 57 minutes. Djokovic becomes the first player since Bob Falkenberg at the 1948 Wimbledon Championships to save multiple match points and win a Wimbledon final.
18 July  MPs vote again in favour of amendments to stop the next prime minister proroguing Parliament in the autumn to facilitate a no-deal Brexit.

links.text: -"Jeremy Hunt apologises after failing to vote with government on prorogation by mistake â€“ live news". The Guardian. 18 July 2019. Retrieved 18 July 2019.-
-"Brexit: MPs back bid to block Parliament suspension". BBC News. BBC. 18 July 2019. Retrieved 18 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: 19 July  The Iranian Navy of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps captures British tanker Stena Impero and temporarily seizes British-operated and Liberian-flagged tanker Mesdar in the Persian Gulf. The Foreign Secretary, Jeremy Hunt, warns there will be "serious consequences" if Iran does not release the tanker.

links.text: -"Tensions soar after Iran seizes tanker: Live updates". www.cnn.com. 19 July 2019.-
-"Second tanker in Gulf turns sharply towards Iran, Refinitiv data shows". finance.yahoo.com. 19 July 2019.-
-"Iran seizes British tanker in Strait of Hormuz". BBC News. 20 July 2019 â€“ via BBC.-

Data.event_text: Conservative MP for Dover, Charlie Elphicke, is charged with three counts of sexual assault against two women.

links.text: -"Charlie Elphicke: Tory MP charged with sexual assault". BBC News. BBC. 22 July 2019. Retrieved 22 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: Carl Beech is found guilty of making false allegations of murder and child sexual abuse against UK public figures. He is sentenced to 18 years in prison on 26 July.

links.text: -"Carl Beech trial: 'VIP abuse' accuser guilty of false claims". BBC News. BBC. 22 July 2019. Retrieved 22 July 2019.-
-"Carl Beech: 'VIP abuse' accuser jailed for 18 years". BBC News. BBC. 26 July 2019. Retrieved 26 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: Jo Swinson is elected by party members as the new leader of the Liberal Democrats, succeeding Sir Vince Cable. She becomes both the first woman to lead the party and its youngest ever leader at age 39.

links.text: -"Lib Dems: Jo Swinson elected new leader". BBC News. BBC. 22 July 2019. Retrieved 22 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: 23 July  Boris Johnson is chosen as the new Conservative Party leader in a ballot of party members, beating Jeremy Hunt by 92,153 votes to 46,656.

links.text: -"Boris Johnson wins race to be Tory leader and PM". BBC News. BBC. 23 July 2019. Retrieved 23 July 2019.-
-"Boris Johnson elected new Tory leader". The Guardian. 23 July 2019. Retrieved 23 July 2019.-

Data.event_text: Parts of the Derbyshire towns of Whaley Bridge, Furness Vale and New Mills are evacuated, with 1,500 residents being moved as a precaution, after concrete slabs on the dam spillway of the Toddbrook Reservoir partially collapse.

links.text: -"Whaley Bridge dam collapse: Town evacuated over Toddbrook Reservoir fears". BBC News. 1 August 2019.-

-Slater, Chris; Wilkinson, Damon; Britton, Paul; Fitzgerald, Todd; Yarwood, Sam (1 August 2019). "Thousands of Whaley Bridge residents evacuated as 'danger to life' warning issued over fears dam could burst". Manchester Evening News.-

Data.event_text: The government announces an extra Â£2.1bn of funding to prepare for a no-deal Brexit, doubling the amount of money it has set aside for 2019, taking the total since June 2016 to Â£6.3bn.

links.text: -"Brexit: Â£2.1bn extra for no-deal planning". BBC News. 1 August 2019. Retrieved 1 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: Liberal Democrat MP Jane Dodds wins the 2019 Brecon and Radnorshire by-election, beating the incumbent Conservative Chris Davies and leaving the Tories with a Commons working majority of just one.

links.text: -"Brecon and Radnorshire by-election: Lib Dems beat Conservatives". BBC News. 2 August 2019. Retrieved 2 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: 5 August  The historic Belfast shipyard Harland and Wolff, which built the RMS Titanic and other well-known ships, ceases trading.

links.text: -"Sound of silence: will shipyard that built Titanic vanish into history?". The Guardian. 9 August 2019. Retrieved 9 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: Data from the Office for National Statistics shows that the UK economy shrank by 0.2% in the second quarter of 2019, its first contraction since 2012.

links.text: -"UK economy shrinks for the first time since 2012". BBC News. 9 August 2019. Retrieved 9 August 2019.-
-"Recession fears grow as UK economy shrinks on back of Brexit chaos". The Guardian. 9 August 2019. Retrieved 9 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: A major power blackout hits parts of England and Wales, affecting nearly a million people and causing widespread travel disruption.

links.text: -"Major power failure affects homes and transport". BBC News. 9 August 2019. Retrieved 9 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: 10 August  Richard Braine is elected as leader of the UK Independence Party, succeeding Gerard Batten.
15 August  Former Conservative and Change UK MP Sarah Wollaston joins the Liberal Democrats, saying it is the best way for her to fight to keep Britain in the European Union.

links.text: -"Sarah Wollaston: Ex-Tory MP joins Lib Dems". BBC News. BBC. 15 August 2019. Retrieved 25 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: 16 August  The Turkish Armed Forces Assistance Fund (known as Oyak) announces that it plans to take over British Steel by the end of the year.

links.text: -"Turkish army pension fund to buy British Steel". BBC News. BBC. 16 August 2019. Retrieved 16 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: Reports emerge that the BritishCanadian Muslim convert Jack Letts, alleged to be a member of ISIL and nicknamed "Jihadi Jack" by the media, has had his British citizenship revoked by the Home Office.

links.text: -"IS recruit Jack Letts loses UK citizenship". BBC News. 18 August 2019 â€“ via BBC.-

Data.event_text: More than 100 MPs write to Prime Minister Boris Johnson calling for a recall of Parliament to debate concerns that the UK faces "a national emergency" over Brexit.

links.text: -"More than 100 MPs urge Boris Johnson to recall Parliament over 'national emergency' of Brexit". PoliticsHome.com. 18 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: The three remaining cooling towers at Didcot power station, a focal point of the Oxfordshire skyline for 50 years, are demolished. An electricity pole is damaged in the collapse, leaving at least 40,000 homes without power.

links.text: -"Didcot power station towers demolished". BBC News. 18 August 2019. Retrieved 18 August 2019.-
-"Didcot power station: homes without electricity after towers demolished". The Guardian. 18 August 2019. Retrieved 18 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: 22 August  Boris Johnson meets French president Emmanuel Macron in Paris, insisting that the Brexit impasse can be broken "with energy and creativity". Macron reiterates that the Republic of IrelandNorthern Ireland backstop plan is "indispensable" to preserving political stability and the single market.

links.text: -"Brexit: Backstop indispensable, Macron tells Johnson". BBC News. 22 August 2019. Retrieved 22 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: 23 August  Boris Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn express concern over major fires in the Amazon rainforest, ahead of the latest G7 summit. A spokesperson for the Department for International Trade states "The UK remains committed to protecting the world's rainforests and will continue to do so in Brazil through our international climate finance programmes."

links.text: -"Boris Johnson 'deeply concerned' by fires raging in the Amazon". The Guardian. 23 August 2019. Retrieved 23 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: 24 August  After video footage emerges of himself at Jeffrey Epstein's mansion in 2010, Prince Andrew defends his former friendship with the convicted sex offender, saying "at no stage" did he "see or suspect" any criminal behaviour.

links.text: -"Footage shows duke inside Epstein's mansion". Sky News. 19 August 2019. Retrieved 24 August 2019.-
-"Prince Andrew: I did not suspect Epstein's behaviour". BBC News. 24 August 2019. Retrieved 24 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: 25 August  The UK experiences its hottest late August bank holiday weekend on record, with temperatures reaching 33.3Â Â°C (91.9Â Â°F) in west London. The record for August bank holiday Monday is also broken the following day.

links.text: -"UK to bask in sunshine on Bank Holiday Monday". BBC News. 26 August 2019. Retrieved 26 August 2019.-
-"UK weather: Hottest late August Bank Holiday Monday on record". BBC News. 26 August 2019. Retrieved 26 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: 26 August  The UK's biggest ever fracking-related tremor is recorded, with a magnitude of 2.9 reported at a Cuadrilla site near Blackpool.

links.text: -"Latest fracking tremor believed to be UK's biggest yet". The Guardian. 26 August 2019. Retrieved 26 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: Opposition MPs gather in Church House, Westminster, where they agree to form "an alternative parliament" if Boris Johnson attempts to force a no-deal Brexit by prorogation. They sign a declaration, calling this threat "an undemocratic outrage at such a crucial moment for our country, and a historic constitutional crisis". Downing Street accuses the MPs of trying to sabotage negotiations with the EU.

links.text: -"Brexit: Opposition MPs agree strategy to block no deal". BBC News. 27 August 2019. Retrieved 27 August 2019.-
-"MPs pledge to form alternative parliament in case of prorogation". The Guardian. 27 August 2019. Retrieved 27 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: Bury F.C. are expelled from the English Football League after a takeover bid collapses.

28 August  Boris Johnson asks the Queen to suspend Parliament from early September until 14 October. Following precedent, she approves the request. While many Brexit supporters welcome the move, the action receives widespread condemnation from those in favour of the UK remaining in the EU, triggering protests both in London and around the country.

links.text: -"Suspension of parliament: MPs react with fury and Davidson set to quit after Johnson move â€“ live news". The Guardian. 28 August 2019. Retrieved 28 August 2019.-
-"Parliament suspension: Queen approves PM's plan". BBC News. 28 August 2019. Retrieved 28 August 2019.-

Data.event_text: 2 September  In a speech outside 10 Downing Street, Boris Johnson states his opposition to calling a general election and urges MPs not to vote for "another pointless delay" to Brexit.

links.text: -"Brexit: PM urges MPs to back him to avoid election". BBC News. 2 September 2019. Retrieved 2 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: Pound sterling falls below $1.20, its lowest level since , before recovering the day's losses.

links.text: -"Pound volatile in further Brexit turmoil". BBC News. 3 September 2019. Retrieved 3 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: The government loses its majority in the House of Commons after Conservative MP Phillip Lee crosses the floor to join the Liberal Democrats.

links.text: -"Brexit: Tory MP defects ahead of crucial no-deal vote". BBC News. 3 September 2019. Retrieved 3 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: MPs opposed to a No-deal Brexit take control of House of Commons business by 328 votes to 301. Johnson responds by telling MPs he will now push for an October general election.

links.text: -"Brexit: No-deal opponents defeat government". BBC News. 3 September 2019. Retrieved 3 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: Boris Johnson withdraws the whip from 21 Conservative MPs who voted against the government, including several former Cabinet Ministers. Notable among them are Father of The House, Ken Clarke, who had served as an MP since the 1970 general election, and Sir Nicholas Soames, grandson of former UK Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

links.text: -"Tory rebels: Full list of 21 MPs to lose the whip over Brexit vote, from Ken Clarke to Nicholas Soames". i. 4 September 2019. Retrieved 4 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: A bill intended to block the possibility of the UK leaving the EU without a deal passes its first Commons vote by 329 to 300.

links.text: -"Brexit: MPs back bill to block no deal". BBC News. 4 September 2019. Retrieved 4 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: A Scottish judge rejects a call by 75 parliamentarians to have the government's postponement of parliament declared illegal. The judge rules that it is for politicians and voters to judge, and not the courts.

links.text: -"Brexit: Judge rejects parliament shutdown legal challenge". BBC News. 4 September 2019. Retrieved 4 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: MPs reject Boris Johnson's motion to call a snap general election for October, failing to achieve the two-thirds Commons majority needed under the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, in a vote of 298 to 56. Labour MPs abstain from the vote.

links.text: -"Boris Johnson's call for general election rejected by MPs". BBC News. 4 September 2019. Retrieved 4 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: Former Labour and Change UK MP Luciana Berger joins the Liberal Democrats.

links.text: -"Ex-Labour MP Luciana Berger switches to Lib Dems". BBC News. 5 September 2019. Retrieved 5 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: Jo Johnson, brother of Boris Johnson, resigns as an MP and minister, stating he is "torn between family and national interest".

links.text: -"Jo Johnson quits as MP and minister". BBC News. 5 September 2019. Retrieved 5 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: The bill designed to prevent a no deal Brexit is passed by the House of Lords.
Opposition parties agree not to back any further government calls for a general election in mid-October.
The High Court rejects a case brought by anti-Brexit campaigner Gina Miller over the suspension of parliament, ruling that it is lawful.

links.text: -"Brexit: Decision to suspend Parliament ruled lawful by High Court". BBC News. BBC. 6 September 2019. Retrieved 6 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd resigns from the Cabinet and surrenders the Conservative Party whip, saying she cannot "stand by" while "loyal moderate Conservatives are expelled".

links.text: -"Amber Rudd quits cabinet and Conservative party". BBC News. BBC. 7 September 2019. Retrieved 7 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: Former Labour and Change UK MP Angela Smith joins the Liberal Democrats.

links.text: -"Angela Smith: Former Labour MP joins the Lib Dems". BBC News. BBC. 7 September 2019. Retrieved 7 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: John Bercow announces that he will stand down as Speaker of the House of Commons on 31 October, or at the next general election, depending on which comes first.

links.text: -"Commons Speaker John Bercow to stand down". BBC News. BBC. 9 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: The Benn bill, intended to stop Britain leaving the EU without a deal, is granted royal assent.

links.text: -"No-deal Brexit officially blocked in law". Metro. 9 September 2019. Retrieved 9 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: By a vote of 311 to 302, MPs back a motion calling for the publication of all government communications relating to no-deal Brexit planning and the suspension of Parliament.

links.text: -Brexit: MPs order Boris Johnson to hand over government communications about parliament suspension and no-deal planning, by Ashley Cowburn, 9 September 2019, Independent.co.uk website.-

Data.event_text: A second government motion calling for an early general election fails to achieve the required super-majority, with 293 MPs voting in favour of it.

links.text: -"Brexit: Boris Johnson's second attempt to trigger election fails". BBC News. 10 September 2019. Retrieved 10 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: 10 September  Parliament is prorogued amid unprecedented protests in the House of Commons from opposition MPs, with some holding up signs saying "silenced".

links.text: -"Brexit: Protests as five-week Parliament suspension begins". BBC News. BBC. 10 September 2019. Retrieved 10 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: Three judges at Scotland's highest civil court rule that the government's prorogation of the UK Parliament is unlawful "and is thus null and of no effect." The UK's Supreme Court in London is to hear the government's appeal against the ruling next week.

links.text: -"Brexit: Scottish judges rule Parliament suspension is unlawful". BBC News. BBC. 11 September 2019. Retrieved 11 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: Around 40 MPs return to work in Parliament, in protest at its suspension and to show their support for the Scottish ruling that the government's decision to prorogue is illegal.

links.text: -"Brexit: No 10 resists demands to recall parliament after Scottish prorogation ruling â€“ live news". The Guardian. 11 September 2019. Retrieved 11 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: In response to a motion passed by MPs on 9 September to force its release, the government publish a five-page document covering the no-deal contingency plan, Operation Yellowhammer. Ministers block the publication of personal communications about Parliament's prorogation, which were also covered by the motion.

links.text: -"Parliament suspension: Government refuses to publish No 10 communications". BBC News. BBC. 11 September 2019. Retrieved 11 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: Downing Street rules out the possibility of an electoral pact between the Conservatives and the Brexit Party.

links.text: -"Brexit: Nigel Farage election pact proposal rejected by No 10". BBC News. BBC. 11 September 2019. Retrieved 11 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: 12 September  The High Court in Belfast rejects a legal challenge against a no-deal Brexit that was brought on the argument it breaches the Good Friday Agreement.

links.text: -Bowcott, Owen (12 September 2019). "Northern Irish court dismisses case against no-deal Brexit". The Guardian.-

Data.event_text: 13 September  Former English Defence League leader Tommy Robinson is released from prison after nine weeks.

links.text: -"Tommy Robinson released from jail after just two months of sentence". The Scotsman. Johnston Press. 13 September 2019. Retrieved 14 September 2019.-
-Christian, Bonnie (13 September 2019). "Tommy Robinson released from maximum security prison after nine weeks". London Evening Standard. Retrieved 14 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: Ex-Conservative MP Sam Gyimah, one of the 21 rebels who had the whip removed on 3 September, joins the Liberal Democrats.

links.text: -"Former Conservative MP Sam Gyimah joins Lib Dems". BBC News. BBC. 14 September 2019. Retrieved 14 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: Facebook removes a Conservative Party advertisement saying it "misused" their advertising platform in the way it presented figures from a BBC News story about the amount of money being invested in schools.

links.text: -"Facebook removes altered Conservative advertisement". BBC News. BBC. 14 September 2019. Retrieved 14 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: 15 September  At their annual party conference in Bournemouth, members of the Liberal Democrats vote to scrap Brexit without a second referendum if they win the next general election.

links.text: -"Lib Dems pledge to cancel Brexit if they win general election". BBC News. BBC. 15 September 2019. Retrieved 15 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: 17 September  The hearing of the prorogation of Parliament appeal begins at the Supreme Court in London, to decide whether the act of suspending Parliament is justiciable and lawful.

links.text: -Casciani, Dominic (16 September 2019). "What is the UK Supreme Court?". BBC News. Retrieved 20 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: 19 September  The Supreme Court hearing of the prorogation appeal concludes after three days and a decision is expected to be given early in the next week.

Some of the largest climate change protests ever seen are held in towns and cities across the UK as part of a worldwide day of strikes and protests, led by young people and adults, to demand action on carbon emissions.

links.text: -"Climate strike: Thousands protest across UK". BBC News. 20 September 2019. Retrieved 20 September 2019.-
-"Global climate strike: Greta Thunberg and school students lead climate crisis protest â€“ live updates". The Guardian. 20 September 2019. Retrieved 20 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: An American woman says she had sex with Prince Andrew as a 17-year-old and was "trafficked" to the prince. The Duke of York denies having "any form of sexual contact or relationship" with her.

links.text: -"Prince Andrew 'was an abuser', says Epstein accuser". BBC. 20 September 2019. Retrieved 20 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: 22 September  An article in The Sunday Times accuses Prime Minister Boris Johnson of misconduct in office while Mayor of London, alleging that US businesswoman Jennifer Arcuri received favourable treatment with the awarding of grants to her company because of her friendship with Johnson.

links.text: -Weaver, Matthew (22 September 2019). "Boris Johnson urged to justify 'awarding public funds to close friend'". The Guardian. Retrieved 28 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: 23 September  Travel company Thomas Cook collapses after 178 years in business, triggering the largest ever peacetime repatriation as 150,000 holidaymakers are left stranded.

links.text: -"Thomas Cook collapses as last-ditch rescue talks fail". BBC. 23 September 2019. Retrieved 23 September 2019.-

Data.event_text: The Office for National Statistics reports that 726 homeless people died in England and Wales in 2018, a 22% rise from 2017 and the highest increase since records began.

links.text: -"Homeless deaths in 2018 rise at highest level â€“ ONS". The Guardian. 1 October 2019. Retrieved 1 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Torrential rain brings flooding to many parts of Great Britain with dozens of warnings issued by the Environment Agency. Some areas in the Midlands, Wales and southern England are hit by a week's rain in just one hour.

links.text: -"UK weather: Torrential rain brings floods across Britain". BBC News. 1 October 2019. Retrieved 1 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Johnson publishes his Brexit plan, which includes proposals to replace the Irish backstop. It would create an "all-island regulatory zone", meaning that Northern Ireland essentially stays in the European Single Market for agricultural and industrial goods.

links.text: -"Government publishes Brexit proposals". BBC News. 2 October 2019. Retrieved 2 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: The government announces fresh plans to prorogue parliament, from 814 October to allow them to bring the current parliamentary session to an end and introduce a new Queen's Speech.

links.text: -"Parliament to be prorogued next Tuesday". BBC News. BBC. 2 October 2019. Retrieved 2 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: The government assures the highest civil court in Scotland that Boris Johnson will send a letter to the EU seeking an extension to Article 50 as required by the Benn Act.

links.text: -"Brexit: Boris Johnson will send extension letter â€“ court document". BBC News. BBC. 4 October 2019. Retrieved 4 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Prince Harry begins legal action against the owners of The Sun and the Daily Mirror, in relation to alleged phone-hacking.

links.text: -"Harry sues Sun and Mirror's owners in phone-hacking claim". BBC News. BBC. 4 October 2019. Retrieved 4 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: 2019 Totnes bus crash More than fifty people are injured after a double-decker bus crashes and overturns on the A385 between Totnes and Paignton in Devon.

links.text: -"Totnes bus crash: Passengers hurt as double-decker overturns". BBC News. BBC. 5 October 2019. Retrieved 5 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab says he has called the US ambassador to the United Kingdom to express his "disappointment" that a US diplomat's wife who is the subject of a police investigation following a fatal road crash has left the UK.

links.text: -"Harry Dunn crash: Mum appeals for US suspect's return". BBC News. BBC. 5 October 2019. Retrieved 5 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Lucia Lucas becomes the first transgender singer to perform with the English National Opera in London.

links.text: -"Lucia Lucas: Making UK operatic debut at the ENO". BBC News. BBC. 5 October 2019. Retrieved 5 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Essex Police confirm that a 32-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder after three men were found dead at an address in Colchester the previous evening.

links.text: -"Murder arrest after three men found dead in Colchester". BBC News. BBC. 6 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Flights repatriating the final 4,800 Thomas Cook holidaymakers stranded abroad following the company's collapse take off, bringing to an end Operation Matterhorn, the largest peacetime repatriation operation that has seen more than 150,000 people brought back to the UK.

links.text: -"Thomas Cook: Remaining 4,800 passengers set for return". BBC News. BBC. 6 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: A Downing Street source says that a Brexit deal is now "essentially impossible" after a phone call between the Prime Minister and German chancellor Angela Merkel. The Brexit spokesman for Angela Merkel's CDU parliamentary group says the unattributable remark "does not ring true".

links.text: -"Brexit: Deal essentially impossible, No 10 source says after PM-Merkel call". BBC News. BBC. 8 October 2019. Retrieved 8 October 2019.-
-"Merkel ally says No 10's telephone call briefing probably part of anti-German blame game". The Guardian. 8 October 2019. Retrieved 8 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Parliament is prorogued until 14 October.

links.text: -"UK Parliament prorogation: Shutdown begins after calm ceremony as threat of no-deal Brexit looms". London Evening Standard. 8 October 2019. Retrieved 9 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: The Government announces plans for a special Saturday sitting of Parliament for 19 October to discuss Brexit options.

links.text: -"Brexit: Special sitting for MPs to decide UK's future". BBC News. BBC. 9 October 2019. Retrieved 9 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Welsh Assembly AMs vote 4313 to rename the legislature with a bilingual name, calling it both Senedd Cymru and the Welsh Parliament.

links.text: -"AMs back renaming Welsh Assembly to Senedd Cymru and Welsh Parliament". BBC News. BBC. 9 October 2019. Retrieved 9 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: 10 October  Boris Johnson and his Irish counterpart, Taoiseach Leo Varadkar hold talks at Thornton Manor in north west England aimed at reaching an agreement over Northern Ireland's status after Brexit.

links.text: -"Brexit: Boris Johnson and Leo Varadkar 'can see pathway to a deal'". BBC News. BBC. 10 October 2019. Retrieved 10 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: The Arndale Centre in Manchester is evacuated after a number of stabbings, in which four people are injured. A man in his 40s is arrested on suspicion of planning an act of terrorism.

links.text: -"Manchester Arndale stabbings: Man arrested as centre evacuated". BBC News. BBC. 11 October 2019. Retrieved 11 October 2019.-
-"Manchester Arndale stabbings suspect arrested for terrorism offence". The Guardian. 11 October 2019. Retrieved 11 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: The pound has its biggest rally against the dollar since the Brexit vote, amid hopes that a deal could be reached before the deadline on 31 October.

links.text: -"Pound surges as hopes of Brexit deal rise". The Guardian. 11 October 2019. Retrieved 11 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Canonisation of John Henry Newman Cardinal John Henry Newman (d. 1890) is canonised by Pope Francis in St. Peter's Square, Vatican City, in the presence of Prince Charles and representatives of the Anglican church, making Newman the first English person who has lived since the 17th century to be recognised officially as a saint by the Roman Catholic Church.

links.text: -"Pope at Canonization Mass". Vatican News. 13 October 2019. Retrieved 13 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Convicted serial sex offender Richard Huckle is stabbed to death in his cell at HMP Full Sutton.

links.text: -"Paedophile Richard Huckle 'murdered' in prison". The Guardian. 14 October 2019. Retrieved 14 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Following the test explosion in July, four of the remaining seven cooling towers are demolished at Ferrybridge C Power Station in West Yorkshire.
The Queen's Speech during Parliament's State Opening sets out 26 bills, including the plans for Brexit.

links.text: -"Queen's Speech: New laws on crime, health and the environment". BBC News. 14 October 2019. Retrieved 14 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Extinction Rebellion protests are banned across London by the Metropolitan Police.

links.text: -"Extinction Rebellion: Police ban London protests". BBC News. 15 October 2019. Retrieved 15 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: 17 October  The UK and EU agree a new Brexit withdrawal agreement, but the DUP confirm they will not support its passage through Parliament.

links.text: -"Brexit: EU and UK reach deal but DUP refuses support". BBC News. 17 October 2019. Retrieved 17 October 2019.-
-"Boris Johnson and EU reach Brexit deal without DUP backing". The Guardian. 17 October 2019. Retrieved 17 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Sainsbury's becomes the first major supermarket to stop selling fireworks at its 2,300 stores across the UK.

links.text: -"Sainsbury's to stop selling fireworks". BBC News. 18 October 2019. Retrieved 18 October 2019.-

Data.event_text: Churchwarden Ben Field is convicted at Oxford Crown Court of murdering author Peter Farquhar so as to inherit his estate. The court heard that Peter Farquhar was the victim of a sustained gaslighting plot before being killed in a manner staged by Field to look like an accident at his home in Maids Moreton, Buckinghamshire. Field is jailed for a minimum term of 36 years.

links.text: -"Maids Moreton: Ben Field jailed for author's murder". BBC News. 18 October 2019. Retrieved 11 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: A special Saturday sitting of Parliament is held to debate the revised European Union withdrawal agreement. MPs pass an amendment 322 to 306 that withholds Parliament's approval until legislation implementing the deal has been passed, and forces the Government to request a delay to Brexit until 31 January 2020.

links.text: -"Brexit: Special sitting for MPs to decide UK's future". BBC News. 9 October 2019. Retrieved 9 October 2019.-
-Murphy, Simon (9 October 2019). "Parliament set for Brexit showdown on 19 October". The Guardian. Retrieved 9 October 2019.-
